Answer: Among the three bonds, the bond of the view of the body as real is eliminated by seeing suffering.
Question: Why is the view of the body as real only eliminated by seeing suffering?
Answer: Because this view only arises in relation to the realm of suffering.
When one contemplates suffering, this view is then eliminated.
Furthermore, because this view only arises in relation to the realm of effects,
when one contemplates effects, this view is then eliminated.
Furthermore, the bond of the view of the body as real is the nature of inversion.
All inversions are eliminated by seeing suffering.
When inversions are eliminated, this view is also eliminated.
Because they have the same antidote.
Furthermore, this affliction is coarse, and when the first uninterrupted path, the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas regarding suffering, is present, it is then permanently eliminated.
If the afflictions are subtle, then at the time when the uninterrupted path of the later stage, the Diamond-like SamÄdhi, is present, one is able to completely eliminate them.
It is like a garment with stains that are not deeply embedded.
As soon as it is washed, it becomes clean.
If the stains are deeply embedded, one uses strong lye, etc.
One exerts effort in washing it and then it becomes clean.
It is also like a ceramic vessel with grease that has not penetrated deeply.
Washing it with water, it becomes clean.
If the grease has penetrated deeply, one either boils it with hot water or burns it with fire and then it becomes clean.

At the time when the first uninterrupted path, the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine with regard to suffering and the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine with regard to the path, are present, one is able to permanently eliminate them.

It is like a tree whose roots do not penetrate deeply into the ground.
A slight wind blows and it immediately falls over.
A tree with deep roots can only be toppled by a great wind.
Venerable Vasumitra said:
This view of existence arises based on the five aggregates.
When one truly observes and sees the five appropriated aggregates, this view is then eliminated.
Furthermore, this view of existence arises from the notions of permanence, bliss, purity, and self.
When these four notions are eliminated, this view is then eliminated.
The Venerable One said:
This view of existence arises based on the existence of a body and is called the view of existence.
If one observes the body and sees it as devoid of self and what belongs to self, this view is then eliminated.
Therefore, the fetter of the view of existence is only eliminated by seeing suffering.
Just as with the fetter of the view of existence,
among the five lower fetters, the fetter of the view of existence, and among the five views, the view of existence and the view of holding to an extreme are also like this.
Because their intrinsic natures are the same.
Because they are both deluded about suffering.
The fetter of clinging to precepts and vows is of two kinds.
Either eliminated by seeing suffering,
Or it is seen as eliminated by the path.
Question: Why is the grasping of precepts and vows not eliminated by seeing the accumulation and cessation?
Answer: Non-Buddhists only give rise to this grasping of precepts and vows regarding suffering and the path.
That is to say, non-Buddhists can also regard accumulation as a place of defilement,
and can also regard cessation as a place of bathing.
Because they regard accumulation as a place of defilement, they do not give rise to longing.
Because they regard cessation as a place of bathing, they mistakenly give rise to longing.
Because of mistaken longing, they give rise to various unprofitable and painful practices.
As they give rise to unprofitable and painful practices,
their afflictions and defilements increase and defile their body and mind, moving further away from nirvana.
It is like a person who, in order to remove the defilements of the body, bathes in dirty water.
The more they bathe, the more their defilements increase.
Therefore, the grasping of precepts and vows only belongs to two categories.
Furthermore, this grasping of precepts and vows only occurs in two places regarding suffering and the path.
As for occurring in the place of suffering, it is eliminated by seeing suffering.
Those that revolve in the path of cultivation are eliminated by the path of cultivation.
Moreover, this attachment to precepts and vows only revolves in the two realms of impurity and purity.
Those that revolve in the realm of impurity are eliminated by seeing suffering.
Those that revolve in the realm of purity are eliminated by seeing the path.
Moreover, this attachment to precepts and vows is only of two kinds.
Namely, the distinction arisen from internal and external paths.
Those arisen from internal paths are eliminated by seeing suffering.
Those arisen from external paths are eliminated by seeing the path.
Moreover, this attachment to precepts and vows is only of two kinds.
Namely, taking what is not a cause to be a cause and taking what is not the path to be the path.
Taking what is not a cause to be a cause is eliminated by seeing suffering.
Taking what is not the path to be the path is eliminated by seeing the path.
As with the fetter of attachment to precepts and vows,ğŸ”½among the four graspings, it is the grasping of precepts and vows.

Among the three leaks, four floods, and yokes, excluding the views, the remaining floods and yokes.

Question: What is meant by eliminated by seeing suffering in this context, up to what is meant by eliminated by cultivation?
Answer: If the antidote is definite and the object of elimination is definite,
it is called eliminated by seeing suffering up to seeing the path.
If the antidote is indefinite and the object of elimination is indefinite,
it is called eliminated by cultivation.
Furthermore, if the location is determined and the object of elimination is determined,
it is called eliminated by seeing suffering up to seeing the path.
If the location is undetermined and the object of elimination is undetermined,
it is called eliminated by cultivation.

If eliminated by the four knowledges of the dharma and the categories, and the conventional knowledge,

Furthermore, if eliminated by contemplating the truth of suffering,
it is called eliminated by seeing suffering.
Up to if eliminated by contemplating the truth of the path, it is called eliminated by seeing the path.
If one contemplates the truth of suffering,

it is called eliminated by cultivation.
Furthermore, if one contemplates in opposition to the truth of suffering,
it is called eliminated by seeing suffering.
Up to if one contemplates in opposition to the truth of the path, it is called eliminated by seeing the path.
If one contemplates in opposition to the four truths,
and contemplates in opposition to other matters,

Mental factors.

Question: Why is it only asked whether it is associated with feeling?
Answer: Because it is the intention of the author of the treatise.
That is to say, the author of the treatise composes the treatise according to his intention without contradicting the characteristics of dharmas, therefore it should not be criticized.
Moreover, because feeling and the characteristics of feeling are different, it does not contradict accomplishment but contradicts present activity, therefore it is asked in a biased manner.
Not contradicting accomplishment means
that one body may accommodate the accomplishment of the five faculties of feeling.
Contradicting present activity means
that it is definitely not the case that two feelings occur simultaneously.
Moreover, because feeling arises in accordance with the transformation of the faculties,
the five faculties are established within the essence of one feeling, other dharmas are not like this, therefore feeling is asked about in a biased manner.
Moreover, feeling occupies the wheel of the twelve links of dependent arising,
It is like the hub of a wheel, therefore it is asked in a biased manner.
Moreover, since all dharmas return to and converge on feeling, therefore it is asked in a biased manner.
Moreover, if one asks about the association with other faculties except for feeling,
if one asks about the association with the eight faculties such as life, it would be unreasonable, because they are not associated.
If one asks about the association with the five pure faculties such as faith,
it would also be unreasonable, because they are only wholesome.
If one asks about the association with other defiled mental activities such as conceptualization and volition,
it would also be unreasonable.
Because they do not have the characteristics of faculties.
Or because they are by nature afflictions.
If one asks about the association with mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom,
it would also be unreasonable.
Because the characteristics of faculties are not associated with afflictions.
Or because they are by nature afflictions.
If one asks about the association with the mind faculty, it would also be unreasonable, because associated dharmas are established based on the mind.
Moreover, because there is no distinction between the mind and what is associated with it.
Feeling has the characteristics of faculties, is not the substance of afflictions, but can give rise to afflictions, therefore it is asked about its association.

Question: Why is the fetter of doubt not associated with the faculty of joy if in the desire realm,

Answer: Because the mode of activity of joy and dejection is not compatible.
That is, doubt in the desire realm operates with the mode of dejection.

Because the meaning of equality is the meaning of compatibility.

Question: Why is joy in the desire realm coarse?
Answer: Because beings in the desire realm give rise to what should not be given rise to.

How is it that one should not arouse it with regard to objects in the desire realm?

It means that if one sees others stumbling and confused, one should give rise to compassion, yet one laughs in delight. Isn't this coarse? The fetter of doubt in the desire realm is subtle because it is pondering.
